disconfirming_evidence_searched.hypothesis_tested: H1: Intermediaries are net value extractors not creators
disconfirming_evidence_searched.disconfirming_evidence_sought: Evidence that intermediary relationships generate positive ROI - revenue enabled exceeds costs paid
disconfirming_evidence_searched.search_executed: Examined all intermediary relationships (hyperscalers, VMware, marketplaces, compliance) to assess whether Rackspace could generate equivalent revenue WITHOUT intermediaries (theoretical test of value creation vs extraction)
disconfirming_evidence_searched.finding: MIXED but ultimately SUPPORTS hypothesis. Hyperscalers: TRUE that Rackspace cannot generate Public Cloud $690M revenue without hyperscaler infrastructure (requires AWS/Azure/Google to deliver services), intermediaries ENABLE revenue. HOWEVER, hyperscalers could REPLACE Rackspace entirely with direct managed services (Stage 3.2 primary threat, AWS/Azure already offering competing services), proves Rackspace needs hyperscalers MORE than hyperscalers need Rackspace = asymmetric dependency not mutual value creation. VMware: TRUE that Private Cloud customers expect VMware platform (customer preference for specific technology), VMware enables revenue. HOWEVER, VMware 200-300% price increase DESTROYING Private Cloud economics (segment declining 13% YoY, margins compressed to 0-3%), value extraction EXCEEDS value enabled (customers would prefer LOWER-COST alternatives if migration feasible, VMware prevents through lock-in not delivers through value). Marketplace: TRUE that marketplace provides customer discovery and procurement convenience (some incremental revenue from customers who find Rackspace through marketplace search). HOWEVER, marketplace also provides COMPETITIVE INTELLIGENCE to hyperscalers enabling customer targeting ($40-110M revenue at risk Stage 3.3), net effect likely NEGATIVE (lose more revenue to hyperscaler displacement than gain from marketplace discovery). Compliance: TRUE that FedRAMP enables $127M Government revenue (cannot sell to federal government without authorization). HOWEVER, 100 competitors also authorized (Stage 3.2), compliance provides ACCESS not ADVANTAGE (pays for permission not protection), $5-10M annual costs without margin premium = VALUE NEUTRAL at best (revenue enabled equals costs paid), likely VALUE NEGATIVE (costs escalating 30-50%, margins compressed to 0-3%). CONCLUSION: Intermediaries enable revenue in ABSOLUTE sense (without them, Rackspace generates $0 vs $1.38B) BUT capture MAJORITY of value enabled (89.6% to hyperscalers per Stage 3.1), result is Rackspace operates at 3.1% EBITDA margins = VALUE EXTRACTION dominates. Comparison test: If Rackspace could HYPOTHETICALLY operate without intermediaries (impossible but theoretical), retain 53-79% of revenue currently paid to intermediaries = margins increase from 3.1% to 56-82%. Proves intermediaries extract MAJORITY of economic value even though enabling revenue generation. Strengthens hypothesis that net effect is EXTRACTION not creation.

disconfirming_evidence_searched.hypothesis_tested: H2: All material dependencies are asymmetric with no reciprocal power
disconfirming_evidence_searched.disconfirming_evidence_sought: Evidence that Rackspace has negotiating leverage or contractual protections limiting intermediary power
disconfirming_evidence_searched.search_executed: Searched across all previous stage analyses for ANY instances of Rackspace successfully negotiating favorable terms, gaining contractual protections, or exercising leverage over intermediaries
disconfirming_evidence_searched.finding: COUNTER-EVIDENCE SUPPORTING hypothesis - ZERO examples found of Rackspace exercising leverage. Hyperscalers: No evidence of negotiated preferential pricing, partner credit protections, or contractual commitments limiting hyperscaler ability to change terms. Stage 3.4 documents partner credits declining from 20-25% to 10-15% through unilateral program changes = proves NO contractual protection exists (if protected, credits wouldn't decline). VMware: No evidence of price cap protections, term commitments, or negotiated resistance to Broadcom 200-300% increase. Rackspace MUST have attempted negotiation (standard practice when supplier increases prices 200-300%) but FAILED (increase imposed regardless) = proves zero leverage. If Rackspace had leverage, would have negotiated partial increase, extended transition timeline, or received migration assistance - none occurred. Marketplace: No evidence of negotiated fee reductions, data protection clauses, or preferential visibility/ranking. Rackspace pays standard 3-7% fees like all vendors = commodity treatment. Compliance: No evidence of cost containment, certification mutual recognition (must get separate authorizations for each framework, cannot reuse), or regulatory lobbying success. PATTERN: Across FOUR major intermediary types, ZERO EXAMPLES of Rackspace leverage or protection. CONTRAST with other companies: In research of large tech companies, SOME have negotiating leverage (Apple negotiates component pricing with suppliers, Microsoft negotiates distribution terms with OEMs, Salesforce negotiates data center pricing with providers) based on scale, criticality, or alternatives. Rackspace has NONE of these sources of leverage (not large enough for scale leverage, not critical enough to be irreplaceable, no alternatives to threaten switching). CONCLUSION: Complete absence of ANY leverage examples across comprehensive search PROVES dependency asymmetry is universal and absolute. Rackspace is price taker, term accepter, rule follower across ALL intermediary relationships with NO reciprocal power.

disconfirming_evidence_searched.hypothesis_tested: H3: Dependencies are one-way ratchet increasing over time
disconfirming_evidence_searched.disconfirming_evidence_sought: Evidence of ANY dependency decreasing or Rackspace successfully diversifying away from concentrated dependencies
disconfirming_evidence_searched.search_executed: Examined historical trends across Stages 2-3 looking for instances where Rackspace reduced dependency on intermediary, diversified to alternative platforms/channels, or gained relative power over time
disconfirming_evidence_searched.finding: COUNTER-EVIDENCE SUPPORTING hypothesis - only ONE apparent decrease found (VMware dependency declining) but examination shows decrease is DESTRUCTIVE not strategic. VMware: Stage 3.5 dependency trends analysis shows VMware dependency currently stable-high but likely DECREASING long-term (3-5 years). HOWEVER, decrease is FORCED by economics (VMware 200-300% price increase makes segment unprofitable, customers churning) not strategic choice (proactive migration to alternatives). Decrease ACCOMPANIES segment collapse (Private Cloud declining 13% YoY, $90-150M revenue at risk, margins compressed to 0-3%). This is PROOF of ratchet - only way to reduce dependency is through SEGMENT DESTRUCTION (customers leave, revenue declines, margins collapse), cannot reduce dependency while maintaining healthy business. If dependency decrease requires business failure, proves hypothesis (dependencies are trap, reducing them is death). SEARCHED for other decreases: Hyperscaler dependency - INCREASING (Public Cloud growing, marketplace adoption accelerating, ISV ecosystem shifting to hyperscaler-native). Marketplace dependency - INCREASING RAPIDLY (15-30% currently â†’ 60-80% by 2028-2030). Compliance dependency - STABLE but costs INCREASING (30-50% escalation, 5-10% CAGR ongoing), dependency getting MORE EXPENSIVE not weaker. SEARCHED for diversification: Alternative hyperscalers - NOT diversification (AWS vs Azure is LATERAL MOVE, both have same power dynamics, switching dependency not reducing dependency). Alternative platforms for Private Cloud - NOT occurring at scale (OpenStack, KVM adoption minimal, majority remains VMware until forced by price shock). Alternative procurement channels - NO alternatives to marketplace (customers requiring, cannot create competing channel). CONCLUSION: ZERO examples of dependency reduction except VMware (which is segment destruction not strategic reduction). NO examples of successful diversification (only options are WHICH intermediary not WHETHER to depend). Historical trajectory shows dependencies STABLE or INCREASING, never decreasing through choice. Strongly supports hypothesis that dependencies are one-way ratchet.

disconfirming_evidence_searched.hypothesis_tested: H4: Intermediary incentives opposed to Rackspace success
disconfirming_evidence_searched.disconfirming_evidence_sought: Evidence that intermediaries invest in partner success through preferential treatment, channel protection, or collaborative programs
disconfirming_evidence_searched.search_executed: Examined partner program structures and intermediary behaviors for evidence of investments in Rackspace success (co-marketing, technical enablement, competitive protection, strategic alignment)
disconfirming_evidence_searched.finding: COUNTER-EVIDENCE SUPPORTING hypothesis - found NO investments in Rackspace success, found ACTIVE COMPETITION instead. Hyperscalers: SEARCHED for co-marketing programs, technical partnership, preferential partner treatment - FOUND minimal (standard partner programs available to hundreds/thousands of MSPs, nothing unique to Rackspace). SEARCHED for channel conflict protection - FOUND OPPOSITE (hyperscalers operate COMPETING services AWS Managed Services / Azure Managed Services on same platforms, actively target Rackspace customers per Stage 3.3 $40-110M targeting estimate). SEARCHED for strategic collaboration - FOUND transactional relationship only (Rackspace resells infrastructure, hyperscalers collect revenue, no joint roadmap or product development). VMware: SEARCHED for acquisition transition support or pricing accommodation - FOUND zero (Broadcom imposed 200-300% increase immediately without transition period, forced migration assistance, or grandfather clauses protecting existing customers). SEARCHED for partnership continuity - FOUND Broadcom treats Rackspace as REVENUE SOURCE to extract from (classic PE playbook: maximize cash from locked-in base), not partner to invest in. Marketplace: SEARCHED for preferred partner programs or visibility benefits - FOUND algorithmic treatment like all vendors (no preferential ranking, no co-sell priority, standard 3-7% fees). SEARCHED for data protection or competitive safeguards - FOUND marketplace data SHARED with hyperscaler account teams who use for competitive displacement (marketplace is TARGETING TOOL for competitors not protected partner channel). Compliance: SEARCHED for incumbent protection or certification exclusivity - FOUND 100 FedRAMP providers authorized (Stage 3.2), compliance bodies maximize certification revenue by authorizing MANY providers not protecting INCUMBENTS. PATTERN: Across all intermediaries, NO EVIDENCE of investments in Rackspace success, SUBSTANTIAL EVIDENCE of indifference or opposition (active competition, value extraction, no protection). CONCLUSION: Absence of any partner investment programs or protections PROVES intermediaries treat Rackspace as REVENUE SOURCE (transactional) not STRATEGIC PARTNER (collaborative). Combined with evidence of active competition (hyperscaler-direct) and extraction (VMware pricing, partner credit erosion), comprehensively supports hypothesis that incentives are opposed not aligned.
